1→PSYC100 GENERAL PSYCHOLOGY
     2→
     3→TREATMENTS AND THERAPIES
     4→
     5→ Learning Outcomes
     6→
     7→ Biological treatments
     8→ Psychodynamic therapies
     9→ Humanistic therapies
    10→ Cognitive therapies
    11→ Behavioural therapies
    12→
    13→ Major Approaches to Treatment
    14→
    15→Other examples: EMDR, ACT, Schema, DBT, Gestalt, Existential, Attachment-based, couples therapy,
    16→sex therapy, family therapy etc.
    17→
    18→ I - Biological Approaches
    19→ Drug Therapies:
    20→ Most commonly used biological interventions
    21→ Psychopharmacology: the study of how drugs affect
    22→
    23→cognitions, emotions, and behavior
    24→ Three major categories:
    25→ Antipsychotic drugs
    26→ Antianxiety drugs
    27→ Antidepressant drugs
    28→
    29→ A) Drug Therapies
    30→
    31→ Antipsychotic Drugs:
    32→Decrease action of dopamine
    33→Reduce positive symptoms of schizophrenia (e.g.
    34→
    35→delusions and hallucinations)
    36→Little effect on negative symptoms
    37→
    38→ Drug Therapies
    39→
    40→ Antianxiety Drugs:
    41→Designed to reduce anxiety without affecting alertness or
    42→
    43→concentration
    44→Side effects: drowsiness, lethargy, concentration
    45→
    46→difficulties, dependence
    47→
    48→ Drug Therapies
    49→ Antidepressant Drugs:
    50→Four classes:
    51→1.
    52→
    53→Tricyclics
    54→
    55→2.
    56→
    57→Monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitors
    58→
    59→3.
    60→
    61→Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs)
    62→
    63→4.
    64→
    65→Seratonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs)
    66→
    67→ Drug Therapies
    68→ Antidepressant Drugs (continued):
    69→Tricyclics and MAO inhibitors:
    70→Increase activity of norepinephrine and serotonin
    71→MAOs more severe side effects
    72→
    73→ Drug Therapies
    74→Antidepressant Drugs (continued):
    75→SSRIs:
    76→Increase activity of serotonin
    77→Milder side effects than other antidepressants
    78→Reduce depressive symptoms more rapidly
    79→
    80→SNRIs:
    81→Increase Serotonin and NE
    82→
    83→ Drug Therapies
    84→ Criticisms of Drug Treatments:
    85→As much as 90% of effects may be placebo effects
    86→Do not “cure” the disorder
    87→Do not teach client coping and problem solving skills to
    88→
    89→deal with life problems
    90→High relapse rate
    91→
    92→ B) Electroconvulsive Therapy
    93→Patient is given a sedative and a muscle relaxant
    94→Patient is placed on padded mattress, where
    95→
    96→electrodes are attached to scalp
    97→Brief shock (less than one second) is applied,
    98→
    99→causing a seizure of the CNS
   100→Short-term effects: headache, sore muscles,
   101→
   102→confusion
   103→
   104→ Electroconvulsive Therapy
   105→ Useful in treating severe depression, particularly if
   106→
   107→there is a high risk of suicide
   108→Effects can be immediate
   109→No one knows why it works
   110→Used primarily in patients with major depression who
   111→
   112→cannot take or do not respond to medication
   113→
   114→ Electroconvulsive Therapy
   115→ Criticisms of ECT:
   116→Possibility of relapse is high
   117→Possibility of permanent memory loss
   118→Possibility of permanent brain damage
   119→
   120→ C) Psychosurgery
   121→ Psychosurgery: surgical procedures that remove or
   122→
   123→destroy brain tissue in an attempt to change
   124→disordered behavior
   125→Used rarely, as a last resort
   126→
   127→ II - Psychodynamic Therapies
   128→ Focus on internal conflicts and unconscious factors
   129→
   130→that underlie maladaptive behavior
   131→ Goal is to help clients achieve insight
   132→Insight: the conscious awareness of the
   133→
   134→psychodynamics that underlie their problems
   135→
   136→ Psychodynamic Techniques
   137→Free Association: clients verbally report without
   138→
   139→censorship any thoughts, feelings, or images that enter their
   140→awareness
   141→Provides clues about important themes and issues
   142→Dream Interpretation: dreams express unconscious
   143→
   144→dreams, fantasies, and wishes
   145→Analyst helps client interpret the symbolism in the dream
   146→
   147→ III - Humanistic Psychotherapies
   148→ Humanists view people as capable of consciously
   149→
   150→controlling their actions
   151→
   152→People should take responsibility for their own choices
   153→
   154→and behavior
   155→Everyone possesses inner resources for self-healing
   156→and personal growth
   157→Focus is primarily on the present and future instead of
   158→the past
   159→
   160→ Humanistic Psychotherapies
   161→ Person-Centered Therapy/Client-Centered Therapy (Carl Rogers) :
   162→
   163→three important therapist attributes:
   164→ Unconditional Positive Regard: communicated when the therapist shows
   165→
   166→that he or she genuinely cares about and accepts the client, without
   167→judgment or evaluation
   168→ Empathy: willingness and ability to view the world through the client’s eyes
   169→ Genuineness: consistency between the way the therapist feels and the
   170→
   171→way he or she behaves
   172→
   173→ IV - Cognitive Therapies
   174→ Focus on the role of irrational and self-defeating
   175→
   176→thought patterns
   177→Therapists try to help clients discover and change the
   178→
   179→cognitions that underlie their problems
   180→Thought patterns are not unconscious, but they can be
   181→
   182→automatic and ingrained
   183→
   184→ Cognitive Therapies
   185→ A - Rational-Emotive Behavioural Therapy (Albert
   186→
   187→Ellis): ABCD Model
   188→
   189→ A: the activating event that seems to trigger the emotion
   190→ B: the belief system that underlies the way in which a
   191→
   192→person appraises the event
   193→ C: the emotional and behavioral consequences of that
   194→appraisal
   195→ D: disputing (challenging) erroneous belief systems
   196→
   197→   Cognitive Therapies
   198→ B - Cognitive Therapy (Aaron Beck): goal is to identify
   199→
   200→faulty/negative automatic thoughts and to help clients
   201→change these thought patterns
   202→ For example, “I am worthless and cannot do anything right” thought in depression.
   203→ The “Negative Triad”
   204→
   205→Help clients realize that their thoughts, and not the
   206→
   207→situation, cause their maladaptive emotional reactions
   208→
   209→  Cognitive Therapies
   210→ C – Cognitive Behavioural Therapy: CBT is a widely used, evidence-based form of talk therapy that
   211→helps people manage problems by changing the way they think (cognitions) and behave.
   212→
   213→ It is based on the concept that our thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are interconnected. Negative or distorted thought patterns
   214→
   215→can lead to emotional distress and unhelpful behaviors, creating a vicious cycle.
   216→
   217→ CBT focuses on identifying and challenging these unhelpful thoughts, replacing them with more balanced and realistic ones,
   218→
   219→while also encouraging healthier behavioral changes.
   220→
   221→ Uses the ABC model
   222→
   223→E.g. Someone with social anxiety is invited to a work party.
   224→
   225→
   226→A (Activating Event): You arrive at the party and notice a group of colleagues talking, but no one immediately approaches
   227→you to chat.
   228→
   229→
   230→
   231→B (Belief): "They think I'm boring and awkward. Everyone here dislikes me, and I'll never fit in. This proves I'm unlikeable."
   232→
   233→
   234→
   235→C (Consequence): Emotional: Intense anxiety, embarrassment, or shame. & Behavioral: You leave the party early, avoid
   236→eye contact, or stand alone in a corner.
   237→
   238→ V - Behavior Therapies
   239→ Behavioral approaches believe that:
   240→Maladaptive behaviors are not merely symptoms of
   241→
   242→underlying problems
   243→The behaviors are the problem
   244→Problem behaviors are learned in the same ways
   245→normal behaviors are
   246→Maladaptive behaviors can be unlearned by applying
   247→classical conditioning, operant conditioning, and
   248→modeling principles
   249→
   250→ Behavior Therapies
   251→ A - Exposure Therapy
   252→ Treat phobias through exposure to the feared stimulus
   253→ Highly effective for reducing anxiety responses
   254→ Systematic desensitization and Flooding
   255→
   256→   Behavior Therapies
   257→ B - Aversion Therapy: the therapist pairs a stimulus
   258→
   259→that is attractive to the client with a noxious stimulus
   260→in an attempt to condition an aversion to the stimulus
   261→ Examples: alcohol, pedophiles
   262→ More effective if paired with a comprehensive treatment
   263→
   264→program
   265→
   266→ Behavior Therapies
   267→
   268→ Malcolm McDowell in a scene from A
   269→Clockwork Orange. His eyes are clamped
   270→open, forcing him to watch a film
   271→portraying acts of violence and sadism, as
   272→part of aversion therapy. He’d earlier been
   273→given an emetic drug, so that extreme
   274→nausea and violence will become
   275→associated.
   276→
   277→ Behavior Therapies
   278→ C - Token Economy
   279→System for strengthening desired behaviors through the
   280→
   281→systematic application of positive reinforcement
   282→Tokens are given for desirable behaviors; they can
   283→
   284→then be exchanged for tangible reinforcers
   285→Very effective in a wide variety of situations
   286→
   287→  Lecture summary
   288→
   289→ What are biological treatments (e.g. drug treatment)?
   290→
   291→Psychodynamic therapies? Humanistic therapies? Cognitive
   292→therapies? Behavioural therapies?
   293→
   294→

    31→
    32→## 2. COMPLETE WEEK-TO-TOPIC MAPPING
    33→
    34→### Week 1: Introduction to Psychology (Sept 29 - Oct 5)
    35→**Date Range**: 29 September - 5 October
    36→**PDF Source**: `PSYC100 GENERAL PSYCHOLOGY INTRODUCTION.pdf/txt`
    37→
    38→**Learning Outcomes**:
    39→1. What is psychology?
    40→2. A brief history of psychology
    41→3. The relationship between psychology and other disciplines
    42→4. Main areas of psychology
    43→5. The scientific study of human behaviour
    44→
    45→**Key Concepts**:
    46→- Definition: Psychology as the scientific study of mind, brain, and behavior
    47→- Etymology: Greek psyche (mind) + logos (study)
    48→- Major features of science: empirical evidence, scientific method, theories/models, experimentation, falsifiability
    49→- Historical milestones (1879-2025):
    50→  - 1879: Wilhelm Wundt opens first experimental psychology lab (Leipzig)
    51→  - 1883: Stanley Hall opens first U.S. psychology lab
    52→  - 1886: Sigmund Freud begins psychoanalysis
    53→  - 1904: Ivan Pavlov's classical conditioning work
    54→  - 1913-1920: Watson's Behaviourism
    55→  - 1960s: Cognitive revolution (Chomsky, Miller)
    56→  - 2024-2025: AI therapy, telehealth, digital therapeutics
    57→- Psychology connections to engineering, business, economics, political science, EFL
    58→- Scientific challenges: objectivity, experimenter bias, demand characteristics, representativeness, artificiality, internal vs external validity
    59→
    60→---
    61→
    62→### Week 2: Theoretical Approaches to Psychology (Oct 6 - Oct 12)
    63→**Date Range**: 6 October - 12 October
    64→**PDF Source**: `PSYC100 GENERAL PSYCHOLOGY THEORETICAL APPROACHES.pdf/txt`
    65→
    66→**Learning Outcomes**:
    67→- Understanding six major theoretical approaches to psychology
    68→- Comparing and contrasting different perspectives
    69→- Evaluating strengths and criticisms of each approach
    70→
    71→**Key Theoretical Approaches**:
    72→
    73→1. **Biopsychological Approach**
    74→   - Focus: Biological processes (brain, nervous system, genetics, hormones)
    75→   - Methods: Twin studies (MZ vs DZ), adoption studies
    76→   - Key concepts: Heritability, concordance rates, nature vs nurture
    77→   - Criticisms: Reductionism, determinism, ethical concerns
    78→
    79→2. **Behaviourist Approach**
    80→   - Key figures: Pavlov, Watson, Thorndike, Skinner
    81→   - Classical conditioning: UCS, CS, UCR, CR, generalization, discrimination, extinction
    82→   - Operant conditioning: Positive/negative reinforcement, positive/negative punishment
    83→   - Criticisms: Overemphasis on observable behavior, neglect of innate factors, overreliance on animal studies
    84→
    85→3. **Psychodynamic Approach**
    86→   - Founder: Sigmund Freud (also Jung, Adler, Erikson)
    87→   - Key concepts: Unconscious mind, id/ego/superego, psychosexual stages, defense mechanisms
    88→   - Levels: Pre-conscious, conscious, unconscious
    89→   - Criticisms: Lack of empirical evidence, unfalsifiable, overemphasis on sexuality, gender bias
    90→
    91→4. **Humanistic Approach**
    92→   - Key figures: Abraham Maslow, Carl Rogers
    93→   - Focus: Self-actualization, personal growth, free will
    94→   - Maslow: Hierarchy of needs
    95→   - Rogers: Self-concept, unconditional positive regard, conditions of worth
    96→   - Criticisms: Difficult to test empirically, overly optimistic, overemphasis on subjective experience
    97→
    98→5. **Cognitive Approach**
    99→   - View: Mind as information-processing system (computer analogy)
   100→   - Focus: Perception, memory, thinking, problem-solving, decision-making
   101→   - Applications: Memory models, Piaget's cognitive development, CBT, AI
   102→   - Criticisms: Overemphasis on mental processes, reductionist, oversimplified computer metaphor
   103→
   104→6. **Evolutionary Approach**
   105→   - Focus: Natural selection, adaptive behaviors, universal features of mind
   106→   - Key concepts: Mate preferences, sexual selection, parental investment, jealousy
   107→   - Examples: Fear of snakes/spiders, height/dark fears, mate selection strategies
   108→   - Criticisms: Falsifiability issues, reductionism, potential misuse to justify inequalities
   109→
   110→---
   111→
   112→### Week 3: Learning (Oct 13 - Oct 19)
   113→**Date Range**: 13 October - 19 October
   114→**PDF Source**: `PSYC100 GENERAL PSYCHOLOGY LEARNING.pdf/txt`
   115→
   116→**Learning Outcomes**:
   117→1. What is learning?
   118→2. Behaviourist approaches (classical and operant conditioning)
   119→3. Cognitive approaches (Tolman, Kohler)
   120→4. Learned helplessness
   121→
   122→**Key Concepts**:
   123→
   124→**Learning Definition**: Relatively permanent change in behaviour, knowledge, capability, or attitude as a result of experience (excluding maturation, fatigue, temporary states)
   125→
   126→**Classical Conditioning (Pavlov)**:
   127→- Components: UCS, CS, UCR, CR
   128→- Processes: Generalization, discrimination, extinction, spontaneous recovery
   129→- Applications: Phobias (Little Albert experiment), treatment (Little Peter - systematic desensitization)
   130→
   131→**Operant Conditioning**:
   132→- Thorndike: Law of Effect, trial-and-error learning, puzzle boxes
   133→- Skinner: Skinner box experiments, reinforcement schedules
   134→- Four consequences: Positive reinforcement, negative reinforcement, positive punishment, negative punishment
   135→- Schedules: Fixed/variable ratio, fixed/variable interval
   136→
   137→**Cognitive Learning**:
   138→- Bandura's Social Learning Theory: Observational learning/modeling (Bobo doll experiment)
   139→- Tolman: Latent learning, cognitive maps in rats
   140→- Kohler: Insight learning in chimpanzees
   141→
   142→**Special Topics**:
   143→- Preparedness (Seligman): Biologically prepared vs contraprepared behaviors
   144→- Species-specific constraints on learning
   145→- Learned helplessness: Repeated exposure to uncontrollable negative events
   146→
   147→---
   148→
   149→### Week 4: Motivation (Oct 20 - Oct 26)
   150→**Date Range**: 20 October - 26 October
   151→**PDF Source**: `PSYC100 GENERAL PSYCHOLOGY MOTIVATION.pdf/txt`
   152→
   153→**Learning Outcomes**:
   154→1. What is motivation?
   155→2. Drive theory
   156→3. Instinct theory
   157→4. Arousal theory
   158→5. Expectancy-value theory
   159→6. Intrinsic vs extrinsic motivation
   160→7. Achievement motivation
   161→
   162→**Key Theories**:
   163→
   164→1. **Drive Theory (Clark Hull, 1943)**
   165→   - Based on homeostasis
   166→   - Physiological disruptions create drives (internal tensions)
   167→   - Behavior motivated to reduce tension
   168→   - Example: Hunger, thirst
   169→   - Criticism: Doesn't explain dieting, eating when not hungry
   170→
   171→2. **Instinct Theory**
   172→   - Automatic, involuntary, unlearned patterns
   173→   - Examples: Crying (babies), coughing, blinking
   174→   - Buss (1999): Desire to pass on genes
   175→   - Criticisms: Ignores learning/environment, doesn't account for individual differences
   176→
   177→3. **Arousal Theory**
   178→   - People seek optimal level of arousal
   179→   - Low arousal → seek stimulation (watch exciting movie, exercise)
   180→   - High arousal → seek relaxation (meditate, read)
   181→   - Individual differences in optimal arousal
   182→   - Criticism: Neglects emotional/social motivators
   183→
   184→4. **Expectancy-Value Theory**
   185→   - Motivation = expectancy × incentive value
   186→   - Example: Student studies hard because expects success (high expectancy) and values good grade (high value)
   187→   - Criticisms: Subjective, overemphasis on rationality, cultural variability
   188→
   189→5. **Intrinsic vs Extrinsic Motivation**
   190→   - Intrinsic: Activity for its own sake (enjoyment, challenge)
   191→   - Extrinsic: Activity for external reward or avoiding punishment
   192→   - Criticisms: Oversimplification, individual differences, contextual factors
   193→
   194→6. **Achievement Motivation (McClelland & Atkinson, 1953)**
   195→   - Need for achievement
   196→   - Motive for success vs fear of failure
   197→   - Measured through TAT (Thematic Apperception Test)
   198→   - Criticisms: Subjective scoring, may not align with explicit behaviors
   199→
   200→---
   201→
   202→### Week 5: Perception (Nov 3 - Nov 9)
   203→**Date Range**: 3 November - 9 November (Part 1 of 2-week block)
   204→**PDF Source**: `PSYC100 GENERAL PSYCHOLOGY PERCEPTION.pdf/txt`
   205→
   206→**Learning Outcomes**:
   207→1. What is perception?
   208→2. Gestalt Psychology principles
   209→3. Depth perception (binocular and monocular cues)
   210→4. Perceptual constancy
   211→5. Visual illusions
   212→6. Theories of visual perception (Gregory vs Gibson)
   213→
   214→**Key Concepts**:
   215→
   216→**Perception Definition**: The organization and interpretation of incoming sensory information to form inner representations of the external world
   217→
   218→**Gestalt Principles**:
   219→1. Figure-ground separation
   220→2. Proximity (elements close together perceived as group)
   221→3. Closure (complete incomplete forms)
   222→4. Similarity (similar parts belong together)
   223→5. Continuity (follow continuous lines/patterns)
   224→6. Symmetry (symmetrical elements unified)
   225→
   226→**Depth Perception Cues**:
   227→
   228→*Non-Pictorial (Binocular) Cues*:
   229→- Retinal disparity: Slight difference in images between two eyes
   230→- Convergence: Inward rotation of eyes for nearby objects
   231→
   232→*Pictorial (Monocular) Cues*:
   233→1. Relative size (farther objects appear smaller)
   234→2. Interposition/Occlusion (blocked object farther away)
   235→3. Linear perspective (parallel lines converge)
   236→4. Texture gradient (textures denser at distance)
   237→5. Light and shadow
   238→6. Aerial perspective (distant objects hazier)
   239→7. Relative height (higher in visual field = farther)
   240→
   241→**Perceptual Constancy**:
   242→- Size constancy (object size constant despite distance)
   243→- Shape constancy (shape constant despite viewing angle)
   244→- Brightness constancy (brightness constant despite illumination)
   245→- Color constancy (color stable under different lighting)
   246→- Location constancy (world doesn't spin when we move)
   247→
   248→**Visual Illusions**:
   249→- Ponzo illusion, Horizontal-Vertical illusion, Muller-Lyer illusion, Poggendorf illusion, Titchener's circles, Ames room
   250→
   251→**Theories**:
   252→- **Gregory's Constructivist Theory**: Perception is indirect, top-down, uses prior knowledge and hypotheses
   253→- **Gibson's Ecological Theory**: Perception is direct, bottom-up, picks up invariant information from environment (affordances)
   254→
   255→---
   256→
   257→### Week 6: Memory (Nov 3 - Nov 9)
   258→**Date Range**: 3 November - 9 November (Part 2 of 2-week block)
   259→**PDF Source**: `PSYC100 GENERAL PSYCHOLOGY MEMORY.pdf/txt`
   260→
   261→**Learning Outcomes**:
   262→1. What is memory?
   263→2. Encoding, storage, and retrieval processes
   264→3. Multi-Store Model (MSM) - Atkinson & Shiffrin
   265→4. Types of long-term memory (episodic, semantic, procedural)
   266→5. Working Memory Model (WMM) - Baddeley & Hitch
   267→6. Levels of Processing Model (LOP) - Craik & Lockhart
   268→7. Theories of forgetting
   269→
   270→**Key Concepts**:
   271→
   272→**Three Memory Processes**:
   273→1. **Registration/Encoding**: Transformation of sensory input into storable form
   274→   - Acoustic encoding (sound)
   275→   - Visual encoding (images)
   276→   - Semantic encoding (meaning)
   277→
   278→2. **Storage**: Retaining information over time
   279→   - Sensory memory (<1 second)
   280→   - Short-term memory (15-30 seconds, 7±2 items capacity, acoustic coding)
   281→   - Long-term memory (unlimited capacity/duration, semantic coding)
   282→
   283→3. **Retrieval**: Recovering stored information when needed
   284→
   285→**Multi-Store Model (Atkinson & Shiffrin, 1968)**:
   286→- Three separate stores: Sensory register → STM → LTM
   287→- Transfer through rehearsal
   288→- Evidence: Serial position effect (primacy/recency), brain damage studies (HM case)
   289→
   290→**Types of Long-Term Memory**:
   291→1. **Episodic**: Personal experiences tied to time/place (autobiographical, flashbulb memories)
   292→2. **Semantic**: General knowledge, facts, concepts (not tied to personal context)
   293→3. **Procedural**: Skills, habits, motor routines (implicit, expressed through performance)
   294→
   295→**Working Memory Model (Baddeley & Hitch, 1974/2000)**:
   296→- Central executive: Manages attention, coordinates subsystems
   297→- Phonological loop: Stores spoken words, allows rehearsal
   298→- Visuo-spatial sketchpad: Holds and manipulates images
   299→- Episodic buffer: Integrates information into episodes
   300→
   301→**Levels of Processing (Craik & Lockhart, 1972)**:
   302→- Depth of processing determines retention
   303→- Shallow processing: Structural (appearance), phonemic (sound)
   304→- Deep processing: Semantic (meaning) → better retention
   305→- Evidence: Craik & Tulving (1975) - semantic questions produce better recall
   306→
   307→**Theories of Forgetting**:
   308→1. **Decay theory**: Memories fade over time without access/rehearsal
   309→2. **Displacement theory**: New information pushes out old in STM
   310→3. **Interference theory**:
   311→   - Proactive interference (old interferes with new)
   312→   - Retroactive interference (new interferes with old)
   313→
   314→**Special Topic**: Efficient forgetting - Hyperthymestic syndrome (HSAM) shows importance of normal forgetting for functioning memory
   315→

   325→### Week 8: Social Psychology (Nov 17 - Nov 23)
   326→**Date Range**: 17 November - 23 November
   327→**PDF Source**: `PSYC100 GENERAL PSYCHOLOGY SOCIAL PSYCHOLOGY.pdf/txt`
   328→
   329→**Learning Outcomes**:
   330→1. Attribution theories (Naive scientist, Correspondence inference, Covariation)
   331→2. Attribution errors and biases
   332→3. Conformity and group influence
   333→4. Obedience to authority
   334→
   335→**Key Topics**:
   336→
   337→**I. Attributions** (Explaining causes of behavior)
   338→
   339→*Three Classic Theories*:
   340→1. **Heider's Naive Scientist Theory (1958)**
   341→   - People perceive behavior as caused
   342→   - Give causal attributions even to inanimate objects
   343→   - Heider & Simmel (1944): Geometric figures perceived as having personalities
   344→
   345→2. **Jones & Davis: Correspondence Inference Theory (1965)**
   346→   - Draw correspondent inferences from behavior to disposition
   347→   - Factors: Intentionality, social desirability of effects
   348→
   349→3. **Kelley's Covariation Theory (1967, 1973)**
   350→   - Three dimensions:
   351→     - **Consensus**: Do others behave similarly?
   352→     - **Distinctiveness**: Does person behave this way in other situations?
   353→     - **Consistency**: Has person behaved this way before?
   354→
   355→**Attribution Errors and Biases**:
   356→1. **Fundamental Attribution Error (Ross, 1977)**: Over-emphasize dispositional explanations, under-emphasize situational
   357→   - Evidence: Quiz game study, Castro study
   358→2. **False Consensus Effect (Ross et al., 1977)**: Overestimate degree others agree with us
   359→3. **Self-Serving Bias (Miller & Ross, 1975)**: Take credit for success, deny responsibility for failure
   360→4. **Actor-Observer Effect (Jones & Nisbett, 1972)**: Attribute own behavior to situation, others' behavior to disposition
   361→
   362→**II. Conformity and Group Influence**
   363→
   364→*Two Types*:
   365→- **Internalization**: Changing real thoughts/feelings
   366→- **Compliance**: Public agreement without internal change
   367→
   368→*Classic Studies*:
   369→1. **Sherif's Autokinetic Effect (1935)**: Ambiguous situation → internalization
   370→2. **Asch's Line Experiment (1950s)**: Unambiguous situation → compliance (37% gave incorrect response)
   371→
   372→*Factors Affecting Conformity*:
   373→- Group size (increases with size)
   374→- Presence of dissenter (greatly reduces conformity)
   375→- Culture (greater in collectivistic cultures)
   376→
   377→*Explanations*:
   378→- **Informational influence**: Desire to be correct (Sherif)
   379→- **Normative influence**: Desire to be liked/accepted (Asch)
   380→
   381→**III. Obedience**
   382→
   383→**Milgram's Experiment (1974)**:
   384→- 65% administered maximum 450-volt shock
   385→- Participants showed extreme discomfort but obeyed authority
   386→- Before experiment, psychologists predicted only sadists would comply
   387→
   388→**Supporting Studies**:
   389→- Hofling et al. (1966): Nurses gave potentially lethal injections (21/22 complied)
   390→- Sheridan & King (1972): Real electric shocks to puppy
   391→- Zimbardo's Stanford Prison Experiment (1973): Power of social situations, ended after 6 days due to ethical concerns
   392→
   393→---
   394→
   395→### Week 9: Developmental Psychology (Nov 24 - Nov 30)
   396→**Date Range**: 24 November - 30 November
   397→**PDF Source**: `PSYC100 GENERAL PSYCHOLOGY DEVELOPMENTAL PSYCHOLOGY.pdf/txt`
   398→
   399→**Learning Outcomes**:
   400→1. Early experiences and attachment (Harlow, Bowlby, Ainsworth)
   401→2. Development of self-concept (Gallup's mirror test)
   402→3. Cognitive development and Piaget's Theory (4 stages)
   403→4. Zone of Proximal Development - Vygotsky
   404→
   405→**Key Topics**:
   406→
   407→**I. Attachment**
   408→
   409→**Definition**: Intense emotional relationship specific to two people, enduring over time; separation causes stress/sorrow
   410→
   411→*Key Researchers*:
   412→
   413→1. **Harlow's Monkey Experiments**:
   414→   - Monkeys preferred cloth mother (comfort) over wire mother (food)
   415→   - Attachment based on security/comfort, not feeding
   416→   - Isolation studies showed severe long-term emotional damage without attachment
   417→
   418→2. **John Bowlby (1950s-60s)**:
   419→   - Attachment is innate biological system (evolutionary)
   420→   - Critical period: birth to ~3 years
   421→   - Caregiver provides secure base and safe haven
   422→   - Controversy: Emphasized mother (monotropy), but multiple attachments are normal
   423→
   424→3. **Mary Ainsworth's Strange Situation (1970s)**:
   425→   - Identified 4 attachment styles:
   426→     - **Secure (~65%)**: Explores freely, distressed when caregiver leaves, easily comforted
   427→     - **Insecure-Avoidant (~20%)**: Little distress, avoids caregiver on return
   428→     - **Insecure-Resistant/Ambivalent (~10-15%)**: Clings, highly distressed, seeks but resists comfort
   429→     - **Disorganized (~5-10%)**: Contradictory/confused behavior, linked to trauma
   430→
   431→**Effects of Deprivation/Privation**:
   432→- **Reversibility**: Czech twins and Romanian orphanages show recovery possible with intervention
   433→- **Sensitive period**: Deprivation beyond ~6 months increases risk; beyond 24 months very high risk
   434→- **ACEs (Adverse Childhood Experiences)**: Link between early attachment and lifelong health/wellbeing
   435→
   436→**II. Self-Concept Development**
   437→
   438→- Components: Self-image (who am I?), self-esteem (how I feel about myself), ideal-self (who I want to be)
   439→- **Gallup's Mirror Test (1977)**: Chimpanzees recognize self in mirror
   440→- **Lewis & Brooks-Gunn (1979)**: Rouge test with infants
   441→  - Before 15 months: No self-recognition
   442→  - 15-18 months: 5-25% touch rouge on own nose
   443→  - 18-24 months: 75% demonstrate self-recognition
   444→
   445→**III. Piaget's Cognitive Development Theory**
   446→
   447→*Four Functional Invariants*:
   448→- **Assimilation**: Fit new information into existing schemas
   449→- **Accommodation**: Modify schemas or create new ones
   450→
   451→*Four Stages*:
   452→
   453→1. **Sensorimotor (0-2 years)**:
   454→   - Understand world through sensory experiences and motor actions
   455→   - **Object permanence** develops (~9 months)
   456→
   457→2. **Pre-operational (2-7 years)**:
   458→   - Symbolic representation (words, mental images)
   459→   - Limitations:
   460→     - No conservation (appearance changes, properties change)
   461→     - Egocentrism (can't see others' perspective - Three Mountains Task)
   462→     - Irreversibility (can't mentally reverse actions)
   463→     - Animism (inanimate objects have lifelike qualities)
   464→
   465→3. **Concrete Operational (7-11 years)**:
   466→   - Logical operations with concrete objects
   467→   - Can conserve, show reversibility, less egocentric
   468→   - Still struggle with abstract transitivity tasks
   469→
   470→4. **Formal Operational (11+ years)**:
   471→   - Abstract and hypothetical thinking
   472→   - Systematic hypothesis testing
   473→
   474→**IV. Vygotsky's Alternative**
   475→
   476→- **Zone of Proximal Development (ZPD)**: Gap between what child can do alone vs with guidance
   477→- **Scaffolding**: Help provided by more knowledgeable other within ZPD
   478→- Emphasizes social and cultural context (vs Piaget's individual constructivism)
   479→
   480→---
   481→
   482→### Week 10: Intelligence (Dec 1 - Dec 7)
   483→**Date Range**: 1 December - 7 December
   484→**PDF Source**: `PSYC100 GENERAL PSYCHOLOGY INTELLIGENCE.pdf/txt`
   485→
   486→**Learning Outcomes**:
   487→1. Defining intelligence
   488→2. Four major theories of intelligence
   489→3. Intelligence testing methods
   490→4. Gender differences in IQ
   491→5. Racial differences in IQ
   492→6. The Flynn Effect
   493→
   494→**Key Topics**:
   495→
   496→**Definition**: "A very general mental capability that involves the ability to reason, plan, solve problems, think abstractly, comprehend complex ideas, learn quickly, and learn from experience."
   497→
   498→**I. Theories of Intelligence**:
   499→
   500→1. **Spearman's Two-Factor Theory (1904)**:
   501→   - General intelligence (g) + specific abilities (s)
   502→   - Performance = g + task-specific s
   503→
   504→2. **Cattell's Fluid-Crystallized Theory (gf-gc, 1963)**:
   505→   - **Fluid intelligence (gf)**: Reasoning, novel problem-solving (independent of prior knowledge)
   506→   - **Crystallized intelligence (gc)**: Learned knowledge, skills, experience
   507→
   508→3. **Sternberg's Triarchic Theory**:
   509→   - Three types of intelligence (analytical, creative, practical)
   510→
   511→4. **Gardner's Multiple Intelligences**:
   512→   - Eight types (linguistic, logical-mathematical, spatial, musical, bodily-kinesthetic, interpersonal, intrapersonal, naturalistic)
   513→
   514→**II. Intelligence Testing**:
   515→
   516→1. **Stanford-Binet Test**:
   517→   - Origin: Binet & Simon (1905) - first individual IQ test
   518→   - Current: 5th edition (2003)
   519→   - Mean = 100, SD = 15
   520→   - Balanced verbal/nonverbal scales (based on gf-gc)
   521→
   522→2. **Wechsler Tests** (Most widely used globally):
   523→   - WPPSI-IV (2.5-6 years)
   524→   - WISC-V (6-16 years)
   525→   - WAIS-V (16-90 years)
   526→   - Balanced verbal/nonverbal scales
   527→
   528→3. **Raven's Progressive Matrices**:
   529→   - Non-verbal, culture-reduced
   530→   - Measures fluid intelligence
   531→
   532→**Historical**: Army Alpha/Beta tests (WWI, 1917-1919) - first GROUP intelligence tests
   533→
   534→**III. Gender Differences**:
   535→
   536→- Most IQ tests constructed to show no overall difference
   537→- **Male advantages**: Visuo-spatial tasks (mental rotation ~1 SD above females), mechanical reasoning, quantitative/math
   538→- **Female advantages**: Verbal tasks (synonym generation, verbal fluency ~0.5-1.2 SD above males), some memory tasks
   539→- **Explanations**: Biological (brain size, hormones, evolution) and environmental (socialization, education, gender-differentiated toys)
   540→
   541→**IV. Racial Differences**:
   542→
   543→- **Controversial claim**: Herrnstein & Murray (1994) "The Bell Curve" - 1 SD gap (Black mean=85, White mean=100)
   544→- **Three proposed explanations**:
   545→  1. Test bias (cultural knowledge of dominant group)
   546→  2. Genetics (REJECTED by scientific consensus - race is social construct)
   547→  3. Environment (CONSENSUS view): Systemic inequities, unequal resources, education, health
   548→- **APA Task Force**: Agreed differences exist but attributed to cultural/environmental factors, not genetics
   549→
   550→**V. The Flynn Effect**:
   551→
   552→- **Observation**: IQ scores increased ~3 points per decade across 30+ countries
   553→- **Largest gains**: Fluid intelligence (Raven's Matrices), not crystallized
   554→- **Trend**: Slowing or reversing in developed nations (Norway, Denmark, UK) since late 1990s
   555→- **Explanations**: Better nutrition, longer schooling, cognitive stimulation (TV, puzzles, video games), smaller families, test familiarity
   556→
   557→**VI. Heredity vs Environment**:
   558→
   559→- Both contribute to intelligence
   560→- Twin studies: MZ twins more similar than DZ twins (genetic influence)
   561→- Adoption studies: Children from disadvantaged families show IQ gains when adopted into high SES families
   562→- Interaction between genes and environment
   563→
   564→---
   565→
   566→### Week 11: Psychopathology (Dec 22 - Dec 28)
   567→**Date Range**: 22 December - 28 December
   568→**PDF Source**: `PSYC100 GENERAL PSYCHOLOGY PSYCHOPATHOLOGY.pdf/txt`
   569→
   570→**Learning Outcomes**:
   571→1. What is abnormality?
   572→2. Classification systems (DSM-5, ICD)
   573→3. Major categories of mental disorders:
   574→   - Anxiety disorders
   575→   - Obsessive-compulsive and related disorders
   576→   - Depressive and bipolar disorders
   577→   - Schizophrenia spectrum disorders
   578→   - Personality disorders
   579→
   580→**Key Topics**:
   581→
   582→**I. Defining Abnormality** (Seven approaches):
   583→1. Deviation from statistical average
   584→2. Deviation from social norms
   585→3. Deviation from ideal mental health
   586→4. Personal distress
   587→5. Others' stress (interpersonal aspect)
   588→6. Maladaptiveness
   589→7. Unexpected behavior (out of proportion)
   590→
   591→**II. Classification Systems**:
   592→
   593→- **Historical**: Kraepelin (1883) - first recognized textbook of psychiatry
   594→- **Current systems**:
   595→  - **DSM-5** (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 5th edition)
   596→  - **ICD** (International Classification of Diseases)
   597→
   598→**III. Major Disorder Categories**:
   599→
   600→**A. Anxiety Disorders**:
   601→1. Separation Anxiety Disorder
   602→2. Selective Mutism
   603→3. Specific Phobia (animals, heights, blood/injection/injury, etc.)
   604→4. Social Anxiety Disorder (fear of judgment in social situations)
   605→5. Panic Disorder (recurrent unexpected panic attacks)
   606→6. Agoraphobia (fear of situations where escape difficult)
   607→7. Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) (chronic excessive worry, 6+ months)
   608→
   609→**B. Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders**:
   610→1. **OCD**: Obsessions (intrusive thoughts) + compulsions (repetitive behaviors)
   611→2. Body Dysmorphic Disorder: Preoccupation with perceived physical defects
   612→3. Hoarding Disorder: Difficulty discarding possessions
   613→4. Trichotillomania: Hair-pulling disorder
   614→5. Excoriation: Skin-picking disorder
   615→
   616→**C. Depressive and Bipolar Disorders**:
   617→1. **Major Depressive Disorder (MDD)**:
   618→   - 5+ symptoms during same 2-week period
   619→   - Must include depressed mood or loss of interest/pleasure
   620→   - Symptoms: Sleep changes, appetite changes, fatigue, worthlessness, concentration problems, suicidal thoughts
   621→
   622→2. **Persistent Depressive Disorder**: Chronic depression 2+ years
   623→
   624→3. **Bipolar I**: At least one manic episode (elevated mood, increased energy, impaired functioning)
   625→
   626→4. **Bipolar II**: Hypomanic episodes + major depressive episodes (no full mania)
   627→
   628→**D. Schizophrenia Spectrum Disorders**:
   629→
   630→*Psychotic Symptoms*:
   631→- **Delusions**: False beliefs (persecutory, reference, grandiose, control, thought, somatic, nihilistic)
   632→- **Hallucinations**: False perceptions (mostly auditory)
   633→- **Disorganized thought/language**: Clanging (nonsensical rhyming patterns)
   634→- **Disorganized behavior**: Blunt, flat, or inappropriate affect
   635→
   636→*Disorder Types*:
   637→1. **Schizophrenia**: Chronic (6+ months), persistent psychotic symptoms, significant functional decline
   638→2. **Schizophreniform Disorder**: Same symptoms but 1-6 months duration
   639→3. **Schizoaffective Disorder**: Psychotic symptoms + mood episodes
   640→4. **Brief Psychotic Disorder**: 1 day to <1 month, full return to baseline
   641→5. **Delusional Disorder**: One or more delusions 1+ month, otherwise normal functioning (erotomanic, persecutory, somatic, jealous types)
   642→
   643→**E. Personality Disorders** (10 types in 3 clusters):
   644→
   645→**Cluster A (Odd/Eccentric)**:
   646→1. Paranoid: Mistrust, suspects exploitation
   647→2. Schizoid: No desire for relationships, emotional coldness
   648→3. Schizotypal: Magical thinking, odd beliefs, eccentric appearance
   649→
   650→**Cluster B (Dramatic/Emotional/Erratic)**:
   651→4. Antisocial: Disregard for others' rights, no remorse
   652→5. Borderline: Unstable mood/relationships, fear of abandonment, self-harm
   653→6. Histrionic: Constant attention-seeking, overly dramatic
   654→7. Narcissistic: Grandiosity, need for admiration, lack of empathy
   655→
   656→**Cluster C (Anxious/Fearful)**:
   657→8. Avoidant: Social inhibition, hypersensitive to criticism
   658→9. Dependent: Excessive need to be cared for, submissive
   659→10. Obsessive-Compulsive PD (OCPD): Rigid perfectionism, orderliness (different from OCD)
   660→
   661→---

   664→**Coverage**: Weeks 8-11
   665→**Format**: Multiple Choice Questions
   666→**Weight**: 30% of final grade

   669→
   670→### Week 13: Treatments and Therapies (Dec 29 - Jan 4)
   671→**Date Range**: 29 December - 4 January
   672→**PDF Source**: `PSYC100 GENERAL PSYCHOLOGY TREATMENTS AND THERAPIES.pdf/txt`
   673→
   674→**Learning Outcomes**:
   675→1. Biological treatments
   676→2. Psychodynamic therapies
   677→3. Humanistic therapies
   678→4. Cognitive therapies
   679→5. Behavioral therapies
   680→
   681→**Key Topics**:
   682→
   683→**I. Biological Approaches**:
   684→
   685→**A. Drug Therapies (Psychopharmacology)**:
   686→
   687→1. **Antipsychotic Drugs**:
   688→   - Mechanism: Decrease dopamine action
   689→   - Effect: Reduce positive symptoms of schizophrenia (delusions, hallucinations)
   690→   - Limitation: Little effect on negative symptoms
   691→
   692→2. **Antianxiety Drugs**:
   693→   - Purpose: Reduce anxiety without affecting alertness
   694→   - Side effects: Drowsiness, lethargy, concentration difficulties, dependence
   695→
   696→3. **Antidepressant Drugs** (4 classes):
   697→   - **Tricyclics**: Increase norepinephrine and serotonin
   698→   - **MAO inhibitors**: Increase norepinephrine and serotonin (more severe side effects)
   699→   - **SSRIs** (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors): Increase serotonin, milder side effects, faster symptom reduction
   700→   - **SNRIs** (Serotonin-Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitors): Increase serotonin and norepinephrine
   701→
   702→**Criticisms of Drug Treatments**:
   703→- Up to 90% of effects may be placebo
   704→- Don't "cure" the disorder
   705→- Don't teach coping/problem-solving skills
   706→- High relapse rate
   707→
   708→**B. Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT)**:
   709→- Procedure: Brief shock (<1 second) causing CNS seizure
   710→- Use: Severe depression, high suicide risk
   711→- Advantages: Immediate effects
   712→- Criticisms: High relapse possibility, permanent memory loss risk, potential brain damage
   713→- Unknown mechanism
   714→
   715→**C. Psychosurgery**:
   716→- Surgical removal/destruction of brain tissue
   717→- Rarely used, last resort only
   718→
   719→**II. Psychodynamic Therapies**:
   720→
   721→- Focus: Internal conflicts, unconscious factors
   722→- Goal: Achieve insight (conscious awareness of psychodynamics)
   723→
   724→**Techniques**:
   725→1. **Free Association**: Verbally report without censorship any thoughts/feelings/images
   726→2. **Dream Interpretation**: Analyze unconscious dreams, fantasies, wishes through symbolism
   727→
   728→**III. Humanistic Therapies**:
   729→
   730→**Person-Centered/Client-Centered Therapy (Carl Rogers)**:
   731→
   732→Three essential therapist attributes:
   733→1. **Unconditional Positive Regard**: Genuine care and acceptance without judgment
   734→2. **Empathy**: View world through client's eyes
   735→3. **Genuineness**: Consistency between feelings and behavior
   736→
   737→Philosophy:
   738→- People capable of controlling actions
   739→- Take responsibility for choices
   740→- Possess inner resources for self-healing and growth
   741→- Focus on present and future, not past
   742→
   743→**IV. Cognitive Therapies**:
   744→
   745→**A. Rational-Emotive Behavioral Therapy (REBT - Albert Ellis)**:
   746→
   747→**ABCD Model**:
   748→- **A**: Activating event (triggers emotion)
   749→- **B**: Belief system (appraisal of event)
   750→- **C**: Consequences (emotional/behavioral)
   751→- **D**: Disputing (challenging erroneous beliefs)
   752→
   753→**B. Cognitive Therapy (Aaron Beck)**:
   754→
   755→- Goal: Identify faulty/negative automatic thoughts
   756→- Focus: "The Negative Triad" in depression
   757→  1. Negative view of self
   758→  2. Negative view of world
   759→  3. Negative view of future
   760→- Help clients realize thoughts (not situations) cause maladaptive emotions
   761→
   762→**C. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)**:
   763→
   764→- Evidence-based, widely used
   765→- Concept: Thoughts, feelings, behaviors are interconnected
   766→- Process: Identify and challenge unhelpful thoughts → replace with balanced/realistic ones → encourage healthier behaviors
   767→- Uses ABC model
   768→
   769→**V. Behavior Therapies**:
   770→
   771→Philosophy:
   772→- Maladaptive behaviors ARE the problem (not symptoms)
   773→- Learned through same processes as normal behaviors
   774→- Can be unlearned through classical/operant conditioning and modeling
   775→
   776→**Three Main Techniques**:
   777→
   778→**A. Exposure Therapy**:
   779→- Treat phobias through exposure to feared stimulus
   780→- Highly effective for reducing anxiety
   781→- Methods: Systematic desensitization, Flooding
   782→
   783→**B. Aversion Therapy**:
   784→- Pair attractive stimulus with noxious stimulus
   785→- Goal: Condition aversion
   786→- Examples: Alcohol treatment, pedophilia treatment
   787→- More effective with comprehensive treatment program
   788→
   789→**C. Token Economy**:
   790→- Strengthen desired behaviors through positive reinforcement
   791→- Give tokens for desirable behaviors
   792→- Exchange tokens for tangible reinforcers
   793→- Very effective in variety of situations
   794→
   795→**Other Approaches Mentioned**: EMDR, ACT, Schema therapy, DBT, Gestalt, Existential, Attachment-based, couples therapy, sex therapy, family therapy
   796→
